On the Hardness of Approximating Stopping and Trapping Sets 111Part of the results were presented at the 2007 Information Theory Workshop, Lake Tahoe. The work was supported in part by the NSF Grant CCF 0644427, the NSF Career Award, and the DARPA Young Faculty Award of the second author.

Andrew McGregor Microsoft Research, Silicon Valley Campus. Email: amcgreg@microsoft.com. â€ƒâ€ƒ Olgica Milenkovic Dept.Â of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. Email: milenkov@uiuc.edu.
Abstract

We prove that approximating the size of stopping and trapping sets in Tanner graphs of linear block codes, and more restrictively, the class of low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes, is NP-hard. The ramifications of our findings are that methods used for estimating the height of the error-floor of moderate- and long-length LDPC codes based on stopping and trapping set enumeration cannot provide accurate worst-case performance predictions.

1 Introduction

In the past decade, the search for efficient and near-optimal decoding algorithms for linear block codes culminated with the rediscovery and generalization of the notion of sparse codes and iterative message passing algorithms. Although Maximum Likelihood (ML) decoding of linear block codes is NP-hardÂ [5], iterative decoders can approach the Shannon limit of reliable communication with polynomial time complexity, provided that they operate on codes with long length that have sparse parity-check matrices, also known as LDPC codesÂ [17]. Decoding is achieved via message passing on the Tanner graph of the code, a suitably chosen bipartite graphical representation of the code which contains a very small number of edges. On such graphs, probabilistic inference of the form of iterative message passing is known to have linear complexity in the code length.

The performance of linear block codes under iterative decoding, and the performance of LDPC codes in particular, depends on the structural properties of their chosen Tanner graphs. For each channel-decoder pair, there exist vertex configurations in the code graph on which the given iterative decoder fails. For some frequently encountered Discrete Memoryless Channels (DMCs), such configurations are known as near-codewordsÂ [26], trapping and stopping setsÂ [12, 31], pseudocodewordsÂ [41, 22], and instantonsÂ [36].

It is known that ML decoders fail when transmission errors are confined to Tanner graph configurations containing codewords, while iterative decoders usually fail to make correct decisions on (strictly) larger sets of configurations. For example, iterative edge-removal (ER) decoders for signalling over the Binary Erasure Channel (BEC) fail on stopping setsÂ [12], a subset of which are the codewords themselves. For the Additive White Gaussian Noise (AWGN) channel and sum-product decoding, failures arise due to subsets of vertices in the code graph that have similar structural properties as codewords, and are consequently termed near-codewordsÂ [26]. As a result, iterative decoders exhibit sub-optimal performance compared to ML decoders, and this performance loss most frequently manifests itself in terms of the emergence of error-floors in the Bit-Error-Rate (BER) curve of the code.

The error-floor phenomena is a problem of focal importance in the theory of iterative decoding, since many practical applications of codes on graphs require extremely low operational BERs. Since such low BERs are well beyond the scope of current Monte-Carlo simulation techniques, several methods were proposed for estimating the height of the error-floor through enumerating small stopping and small trapping setsÂ [34], and exploring dominant instantonsÂ [31, 36]. These techniques operate fairly accurately for codes of very short and moderate length and small minimum pseudoweight, but they are time consuming, and no rigorous analytical study of the performance of these search procedures is known.

Recently, it was shown that the problem of finding the smallest stopping set in an arbitrary code graph is NP-hard to approximate up to a constant termÂ [27]. InÂ [40], it was shown that finding the smallest kğ‘˜k-out set, which represents a straightforward generalization of the notion of a stopping set, is NP-hard as well. Despite the fact that kğ‘˜k-out sets may lead to decoding failures similar to those caused by trapping sets, the results inÂ [40] do not capture the fact that trapping sets are usually characterized in terms of two parameters. Furthermore, the notion of a trapping set is meaningful only in conjunction with a fixed decoding method. Finally, no hardness results for approximating kğ‘˜k-out sets or more general trapping sets are currently known.

The main contributions of our work are three-fold. First, we improve upon the hardness results for approximating stopping sets, presented inÂ [27]. Furthermore, we introduce the notion of a cover stopping set, and show that the problem of finding such a set of smallest cardinality in an arbitrary Tanner graph is NP-hard. Second, we provide a set of new results regarding the hardness of finding trapping sets for Gallager A decoder (GA)Â [4], the Zyablov-Pinsker (ZP) decoderÂ [43, 42], and the product-sum decoder. The third, and most important finding presented in the paper is that these hardness results carry over to the case of LDPC code graphs (provided that the notion of â€œlow-densityâ€ is properly defined). We discuss the impact of these findings on the accuracy of estimating the error-floor based on trapping set enumeration techniques. In addition, we give a brief overview of the theory of fixed parameter tractability (FPT), and show that the minimum cover stopping set problem is FPT.

The paper is organized as follows. SectionÂ 2 introduces the trapping set structures under investigation, as well as their corresponding decoding algorithms. SectionÂ 3 provides a brief overview of a class of NP-hard problems that are used in the reduction proofs of our main results. SectionÂ 4 contains theorems regarding the hardness of approximating classes of trapping sets, while SectionÂ 5 specializes these results for the class of sparse code graphs and short code lengths. In SectionÂ 6 we briefly comment on the accuracy of error-floor estimation procedures relying on exhaustive trapping set enumeration techniques. In SectionÂ 7, we describe the notion of fixed parameter tractability and its implications for stopping and trapping set size estimation. Concluding remarks are given in SectionÂ 8.

Iterative decoders are a class of inference algorithms that operate on Tanner graphs of codes. These decoders are known to compute the maximum likelihood estimates of variables only on Tanner graphs free of cycles. Nevertheless, when applied to LDPC codes that contain cycles, they can approach the Shannon limit on optimal performance with complexity linear in the length of the code.

The messages passed between vertices of the Tanner graphs during iterative decoding depend on the characteristics of the transmission channel, and there usually exist many different iterative decoding methods that can be used for the same channel. For various decoder architectures specialized for the BEC, BSC, and AWGN channel, the interested reader is referred toÂ [32]. For clarity of the future exposition, we briefly describe three of these procedures: the edge-removal (ER) algorithm, the Zyablov-Pinsker (ZP) bit-flipping methodÂ [12, 43, 42], and the regular Gallager A algorithmÂ [7]. The first algorithm operates on outputs of the BEC, while the second two are designed for the BSC. A detailed description of different decoding procedures for signalling over the AWGN channel can be found inÂ [31].

The ER algorithm is used for codes transmitted over the BEC channel, where the input to the channel is a vector c1â€‹c2â€‹â€¦â€‹cnâˆˆğ’subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘2â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ’c_{1}c_{2}\ldots c_{n}\in\mathcal{C}, and the output is a vector v1â€‹v2â€‹â€¦â€‹vnsubscriptğ‘£1subscriptğ‘£2â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘›v_{1}v_{2}\ldots v_{n} over the symbol alphabet {0,1,e}01ğ‘’\{{0,1,e\}}. For a BEC channel with erasure probability pğ‘p, one has Prâ¡[vi=ci]=1âˆ’pPrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘\Pr[v_{i}=c_{i}]=1-p, and Prâ¡[vi=e]=pPrsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘\Pr[v_{i}=e]=p. The ER algorithm assigns to each vertex iğ‘–i in Lğ¿L of the Tanner graph of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} the symbol visubscriptğ‘£ğ‘–v_{i}. It then iteratively searches for vertices in Rğ‘…R adjacent only to one eğ‘’e symbol in Lğ¿L. Due to the even-parity restriction, the corresponding cisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–c_{i} value for such a symbol can be uniquely determined. The decoder terminates either when the correct codeword is recovered or if every every parity-check vertex connected to one eğ‘’e symbol is connected to at least two such symbols. In the latter case, we say that the decoder failed on a stopping set.

Definition 1 (BEC Stopping Sets).

Given a bipartite graph G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E), we say that SâŠ‚Lğ‘†ğ¿S\subset L is a stopping-set if the degree of each vertex in Î“â€‹(S)Î“ğ‘†\Gamma(S) in the induced subgraph GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S} is at least two.

Of independent interest is the problem of determining the size of the smallest stopping set Sğ‘†S such that Î“â€‹(S)=RÎ“ğ‘†ğ‘…\Gamma(S)=R, i.e., the smallest set of vertices that covers each check node in Rğ‘…R at least twice. We refer to such a set as the cover stopping set. If symbols corresponding to a cover stopping set are erased, then the decoding process terminates before proceeding with the first iteration, and no erasure can be corrected.

If symbols with such a property are encountered, the decoder flips their values sequentially. Definition 2 (BSC ZP-Trapping Sets).

Let G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E) be a left-regular bipartite graph with degree â„“â„“\ell. We say that SâŠ‚Lğ‘†ğ¿S\subset L is a ZP-trapping set if the induced subgraph GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S} is such that all vertices in Sğ‘†S are connected to less than â„“âˆ’âŒŠ(â„“âˆ’1)/2âŒ‹â„“â„“12\ell-\lfloor(\ell-1)/2\rfloor odd degree vertices in GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S}.

Another frequently used iterative decoding algorithm for signaling over the BSC that has a complete characterization of trapping sets is the Gallager A algorithm for regular codes with left vertex degree â„“=3â„“3\ell=3. The decoding rule is straightforward: unless all incoming massages to a variable node are identical, the variable node transmits its received symbol. Otherwise, the node transmits the consensus vote. On the other hand, the check-nodes pass on their parity estimates to their neighboring variable nodes.

For the AWGN channel, and message-passing algorithms, no precise analytic characterization of failing configurations is known. Extensive computer simulationsÂ [31, 24] show that errors are usually confined to near codewords, also known as trapping sets or instantons. Roughly speaking, trapping sets resemble codewords in so far that they result in a very small number of unsatisfied check equations (for codewords, this number equals zero). We focus our attention on three such configurations, defined below.

Definition 4 (AWGN (a,b)ğ‘ğ‘(a,b)-Trapping Sets).

Given a bipartite graph G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E), we say that SâŠ‚Lğ‘†ğ¿S\subset L is an (a,b)ğ‘ğ‘(a,b)-trapping set if |S|=ağ‘†ğ‘|S|=a and the induced subgraph is such that Î“â€‹(S)Î“ğ‘†\Gamma(S) has exactly bğ‘b vertices of odd degree. Tğ‘‡T is a majority trapping set if Tğ‘‡T and Lâˆ–Tğ¿ğ‘‡L\setminus T are both good.

Complexity Theory:

A problem belongs to the class NP if it can be solved in polynomial time by a non-deterministic Turing machine. Alternatively, the complexity category of decision problems for which answers can be checked for correctness using a certificate and an algorithm with polynomial running time in the size of the input is known as the NP class. A problem is NP-hard if the existence of a deterministic polynomial time algorithm for the problem would imply the existence of deterministic polynomial time algorithms for every problem in NP. This consequence is widely believed to be false, and hence determining that a problem is NP-hard is a very strong indicator that the problem in computational intractable, i.e., no deterministic, polynomial time algorithm exists for the problem.

For optimization problems, there exists a large body of work that considers approximate solutions rather than exact solutionsÂ [39]. When minimizing a function subject to constraints, we say an algorithm is an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm if it always returns a solution whose value is at most a factor Î±ğ›¼\alpha greater than the value for the optimal solution. For some NP-hard problems, it is possible to show that it is also NP-hard to Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximate the problem. For a more thorough treatment of these and other subjects in complexity theory, the interested reader is referred toÂ [20].

Our Results:

We are concerned with the worst-case computational complexity of the following problems.

  1. 1.

    MinStop: Find a stopping set of minimum cardinality.

  2. 2.

    MinCStop: Find a cover stopping set of minimum cardinality .

  3. 3.

    MinTrapZP: Find a ZP-trapping set of minimum cardinality.

  4. 4.

    MinTrapGA: Given ağ‘a, find a GA-trapping set of minimum cardinality.

  5. 5.

    MinTrapAWGN: Given ağ‘a, find an (a,b)ğ‘ğ‘(a,b)-trapping set with minimum parameter bğ‘b.

  6. 6.

    MinTrapAWGN-elem: Given bğ‘b, find an (a,b)ğ‘ğ‘(a,b)-elementary trapping set with minimum parameter ağ‘a.

  7. 7.

    MinTrapAWGN-maj: Find a majority trapping set of minimum cardinality.

We show that there are no polynomial time algorithms for any of the above problems under standard complexity assumptions. Furthermore, there are no polynomial time algorithms that even approximate the optimal solutions to a guaranteed precision. Many of these hardness results also apply when we restrict our attention to Tanner graphs that correspond to LDPC codes. Our proofs can all be cast as reductions from the NP-hard Minimum Set Cover, Minimum DistanceÂ [37, 38, 15], and Maximum Three-Dimensional Matching problemsÂ [5]. These, and some other relevant problems subsequently referred to, are briefly described in the following section.

4 Hardness of Approximation Results

4.1 Hardness of Approximation for MinStop

We start by showing that MinStop is not approximable within oâ€‹(logâ¡N)ğ‘œğ‘o(\log\,N), where Nğ‘N denotes the description length of the problem, unless P=Nâ€‹Pğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒP=NP. This results improves upon the finding inÂ [27], where the weaker claim that MinStop cannot be approximated within any positive constant was proved. This improvement is a consequence of the fact that our proof relies on reduction from the MinSetCov, rather than the MinVertCov problemÂ [27].

Theorem 1.

There exists a constant c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that it is NP-hard to (câ€‹logâ¡N)ğ‘ğ‘(c\log N)-approximate MinStop.

Proof.

The proof is by a reduction from MinSetCov. Let b=|âˆªiâˆˆ[a]Si|ğ‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–b=\left|\cup_{i\in[a]}S_{i}\right|, and without loss of generality, assume that SâŠ‚[b]ğ‘†delimited-[]ğ‘S\subset[b], for each Sâˆˆğ’®.ğ‘†ğ’®S\in{\mathcal{S}}. Form a bipartite graph G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E) with L={u1,â€¦â€‹ua,x,y}ğ¿subscriptğ‘¢1â€¦subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¦L=\{u_{1},...u_{a},x,y\}, R={v1,â€¦â€‹vb,w1,â€¦,wa,z}ğ‘…subscriptğ‘£1â€¦subscriptğ‘£ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤1â€¦subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘§R=\{v_{1},...v_{b},w_{1},...,w_{a},z\}, and edges

MinCStop:

The proof of TheoremÂ 1 also implies that there exists a c>0ğ‘0c>0 such that it is NP-hard to (câ€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘ğ‘›(c\log n)-approximate MinCStop. This is a consequence of the fact that the family of hard instances considered all had the property that the neighborhood of all stopping sets was all the check nodes. We next show that there exists a deterministic, polynomial-time, Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)-approximation algorithm for MinCStop. This follows because we can relate MinCStop to MinHitSet as follows.

For each râˆˆRğ‘Ÿğ‘…r\in R, create a set of sets Srsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ŸS_{r} that consists of all (|Î“â€‹(r)|âˆ’1)Î“ğ‘Ÿ1(|\Gamma(r)|-1)-subsets of Î“â€‹(r)Î“ğ‘Ÿ\Gamma(r). For example, if Î“â€‹(r)={a,b,c,d}Î“ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘\Gamma(r)=\{{a,b,c,d\}}, then Sr={(a,b,c),(a,b,d),(a,c,d),(b,c,d)}.subscriptğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘‘S_{r}=\{{(a,b,c),(a,b,d),(a,c,d),(b,c,d)\}}. Let ğ’®={Sr:râˆˆR}ğ’®conditional-setsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘Ÿğ‘Ÿğ‘…{\mathcal{S}}=\{S_{r}:r\in R\}. Then QâŠ‚Lğ‘„ğ¿Q\subset L is a hitting set for ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} iff it is a cover stopping set of Lğ¿L. This claim can be proved in a straightforward manner: if ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} contains at least one element, say ağ‘a, from Î“â€‹(r)Î“ğ‘Ÿ\Gamma(r), then it must contain at least two elements from the same set since otherwise, the (|Î“â€‹(r)|âˆ’1)Î“ğ‘Ÿ1(|\Gamma(r)|-1) set that does not contain ağ‘a will not be hit.

Consequently, any Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinHitSet can also be used to obtain an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinCStop. For example the following simple greedy algorithm can be shown to be an Oâ€‹(logâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›O(\log n)-approximation algorithm for MinHitSet: At each step add the element that appears in the most sets from ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} can remove these sets from ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S} can repeat until all the elements chosen appear in every set from ğ’®ğ’®\mathcal{S}.

The greedy algorithm searches for cover stopping sets by going through the list of variable nodes in decreasing order of their degree, and it is straightforward to see that the algorithm terminates after at most (nâˆ’k)â€‹Î´maxğ‘›ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¿(n-k)\,\delta_{\max} steps, where Î´maxsubscriptğ›¿\delta_{\max} denotes the largest degree of any check node in the Tanner graph of the code. As a consequence, this algorithm is especially well suited for LDPC codes, to be formally defined in SectionÂ 5.

4.2 Hardness of Approximation for MinTrapZP, MinTrapGA, and MinTrapAWGN

We show next that the problems MinTrapZP, MinTrapGA, and MinTrapAWGN are computationally at least as hard as the MinCodeword problem.

Theorem 2.

For any constant Î±ğ›¼\alpha, there is no polynomial-time Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinTrapZP, unless Râ€‹P=Nâ€‹Pğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒRP=NP.

Proof.

Recall that unless Râ€‹P=Nâ€‹Pğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒRP=NP, there is no polynomial time MinCodeword problem is Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1)-hard to approximate even under the restriction that the Tanner graph of the code is left regular. This follows directly from the results inÂ [15].

Given a Tanner graph G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E) that is left regular say with degree âŒŠ(â„“âˆ’1)/2âŒ‹+1â„“121\lfloor(\ell-1)/2\rfloor+1, for each node uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L create â„“âˆ’âŒŠ(â„“âˆ’1)/2âŒ‹âˆ’1â„“â„“121\ell-\lfloor(\ell-1)/2\rfloor-1 new nodes in Rğ‘…R each connected to uğ‘¢u. A very similar argument can be used to prove the following claim.

Theorem 3.

For any constant Î±ğ›¼\alpha, there is no polynomial-time, Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinTrapGA, unless Râ€‹P=Nâ€‹Pğ‘…ğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒRP=NP.

Similarly as in the proof of TheoremÂ 2, create for each node uâˆˆLğ‘¢ğ¿u\in L one new node in Rğ‘…R each connected only to uğ‘¢u. Call the new Tanner graph Gâ€²superscriptğºâ€²G^{\prime}. This follows due to the fact that the first condition in the definition of GA-trapping sets is identical to the ZP-restriction, with â„“=3â„“3\ell=3. The second condition in the definition of an GA-trapping set is enforced automatically, since vertices in Lâˆ–Sğ¿ğ‘†L\setminus S cannot be connected to odd-degree check nodes in GSsubscriptğºğ‘†G_{S} due to the fact that all such checks have degree one. Hence any Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinTrapZP yields an Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximation algorithm for MinCodeword and the result follows.

5 Hardness of Approximation Results for Sparse Codes

The fact that a problem is NP-hard usually does not imply that a special instance of the problems is NP-hard. Since iterative decoding algorithms have both linear-time complexity and offer good decoding performance only for special classes of codes, it is important to establish the analogues of the results in SectionÂ 4 for such codes. We provide next a set of results establishing the hardness of approximating stopping and trapping sets for low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes.

LDPC codes are linear block codes for which the parity-check matrix Hğ»H is sparse -i.e., for which Hğ»H has a â€œsmallâ€ number of non-zero entries. More formally, we define an LDPC code as follows. An LDPC code is a code with the property that each variable and check node in its Tanner graph G=(LâˆªR,E)ğºğ¿ğ‘…ğ¸G=(L\cup R,E) has degree at most Î´vsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘£\delta_{v} and Î´csubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{c}, respectively, for some constants Î´v,Î´c>2subscriptğ›¿ğ‘£subscriptğ›¿ğ‘2\delta_{v},\delta_{c}>2 independent on nğ‘›n.

One can establish the even stronger result that the MinStop problem for LDPC codes remains NP hard even for codes with Tanner graphs that avoid cycles of length four. This follows from the same arguments used in the proof of the theorem above, with an additional reference to the hardness of the MinSetCovInterOne problem, which also holds in the setting of sparse codesÂ [23].

Theorem 9.

There exists a constant Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1 such that it is NP-hard to Î±ğ›¼\alpha-approximate MinTrapAWGN-elem in the Tanner graph of an LDPC code.

Proof.

The proof follows along the same lines as the proof of TheoremÂ 5, with the three-dimensional matching problem replaced by its constraint version involving a bounded number â„“â„“\ell of appearances of each element in Xğ‘‹X. âˆ

Theorem 10.

The problems MaxLikeDecode and MinCodeword are NP-hard for LDPC codes.

Proof.

The proof is a direct consequence of the fact that the parity-check matrix used in the reduction from the MaxThreeDimMatch to the MaxLikeDecode problem is sparse (it has column weight three, and the row weight can be made bounded as well by invoking the constraint that any element of Xğ‘‹X cannot appear more than râ‰¥3ğ‘Ÿ3r\geq 3 times). The claimed result follows from the observation that there exists a polynomial-time reduction algorithm from the MaxLikeDecode to the MinCodeword problemÂ [37, 38]. âˆ

As a consequence of the above finding, all trapping set problems described in SectionÂ 4, for which the hardness was established in terms of reductions from the MinCodeword problem, remain NP-hard for the class of LDPC codes.

6 Estimation of the Error-Floor

The error floor is a phenomena inherent to iterative decoders that manifests itself as a sudden change in the slope of the BER performance of a code. Alternatively, it represents a phase transition in the dynamical system of the decoder that prohibits it from attaining a sufficiently low BER. The error floor usually appears at moderate to high signal-to-noise ratios, i.e. for small values of the erasure and error probability pğ‘p of the BEC and BSC channel. For such values of pğ‘p, the codeword error-rate Râ€‹(p)ğ‘…ğ‘R(p) has the form

logâ¡(Râ€‹(p))â‰ƒlogâ¡(NÎº)+Îºâ€‹logâ¡(p),similar-to-or-equalsğ‘…ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğœ…ğœ…ğ‘\log\left(R(p)\right)\simeq\log(N_{\kappa})+\kappa\;\log(p), (1)

where Îºğœ…\kappa denotes the size of the smallest stopping/trapping sets, while Nisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–N_{i} represents the number of such sets. The dominating term in the expression is the linear term Îºâ€‹logâ¡(p)ğœ…ğ‘\kappa\;\log(p).

As a consequence of the results in SectionÂ 4, we have the following result.

Corollary 6.

Unless P=Nâ€‹Pğ‘ƒğ‘ğ‘ƒP=NP, there is no polynomial time algorithm for estimating the error-floor of codes used over the BEC and BSC within an Oâ€‹(1)ğ‘‚1O(1) term.

For the AWGN channel with noise variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}, a heuristic formula for the codeword error-rate was derived inÂ [31], where it was shown that

Râ€‹(Ïƒ)â‰¥âˆ‘Tâˆˆğ’¯Pâ€‹(T,Ïƒ),ğ‘…ğœsubscriptğ‘‡ğ’¯ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğœR(\sigma)\geq\sum_{T\in\mathcal{T}}P(T,\sigma),

where ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} denotes the set of dominant (small) elementary trapping sets for the given code, and Pâ€‹(T,Ïƒ)ğ‘ƒğ‘‡ğœP(T,\sigma) is the probability of decoder failure on a trapping set Tğ‘‡T. It was observed that simulation of decoding can be viewed as stochastic process for finding trapping setsÂ [31]. This, and other methods that rely on combining simulation techniques with â€œaided flippingâ€ methods and greedy search strategies, were all observed to be inefficient when estimating the error-floor of â€œgood codesâ€ - i.e. codes with large minimum stopping and trapping set sizes. In the next section, we show that some problems discussed in the paper has complexity that grows exponentially with the size of the smallest set being sought, but only polynomially with respect to the size of the input (i.e., code length). Consequently, one can easily find the smallest stopping sets of fairly long codes, provided that the size of such stopping sets is not greater than 10âˆ’15101510-15Â [14, 13, 34]. This was observed in several papers, includingÂ [34].

7 Fixed-Parameter Tractability

Parameterized complexity represents a measure of the computational cost of problems that have several input parameters. Problems for which one of the parameters, say Ï€ğœ‹\pi, is fixed are called parameterized problems. There exist problems that require exponential running time in the parameter Ï€ğœ‹\pi but that are computable in a time that is polynomial in the input size. Hence, if Ï€ğœ‹\pi is fixed at a small value, such problems can still be exactly solved in an efficient manner. A parameterized problem that allows for the existence of such polynomial time algorithms is termed a fixed-parameter tractable problem and it belongs to the class FPT, first studied by Downey and FellowsÂ [13].

Many NP-complete problems are fixed-parameter tractable. As an example, the MinVertCov is FPT, with complexity Oâ€‹(Îºâ€‹n+(4/3)Îºâ€‹Îº2)ğ‘‚ğœ…ğ‘›superscript43ğœ…superscriptğœ…2O(\kappa\,n+(4/3)^{\kappa}\,\kappa^{2}), where Îºğœ…\kappa denotes the size of the smallest vertex cover, and nğ‘›n is the size of the input, i.e., the number of vertices in the graph. Despite the fact that MinVertCov is a special instant of MinHitSet with set sizes equal to two, the latter is not known to have FPT algorithms when parameterization is performed only with respect to the size of the smallest hitting set Îºğœ…\kappa. Strong evidence suggests that such an algorithm does not exist, since MinHitSet is Wâ€‹[2]ğ‘Šdelimited-[]2W[2]-complete (for the non-trivial definition of the Wâ€‹[2]ğ‘Šdelimited-[]2W[2] class, seeÂ [14]). It is only known that MinHitSet is FPT when the set sizes are bounded, and parameterization is performed with respect to, say, Îº+Î´maxğœ…subscriptğ›¿max\kappa+\delta_{\text{max}}, where Î´maxsubscriptğ›¿max\delta_{\text{max}} denotes the size of the largest set in the MinHitSet formulation.

In this section, we use the results ofÂ [8, 16, 33] to show that the MinCStop problem is FPT. Furthermore, by invoking the recent results inÂ [11], we show that the problem of enumerating all cover stopping sets is FPT as well.

Theorem 11.

The problem MinCStop for LDPC codes of maximal constant check node degree Î´csubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{c} is in FTP, with best known complexity bound of the form

Oâ€‹((Î´câˆ’22â€‹(1+1+4(Î´câˆ’2)2))Îº+n).ğ‘‚superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘22114superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘22ğœ…ğ‘›O\left(\left(\frac{\delta_{c}-2}{2}\left(1+\sqrt{1+\frac{4}{(\delta_{c}-2)^{2}}}\right)\right)^{\kappa}+n\right). (2)

The algorithm that achieves this bound is a tree search algorithm, seeÂ [16].

Theorem 12.

The problem of enumerating all minimal cover stopping sets in LDPC codes of maximal constant check node degree Î´csubscriptğ›¿ğ‘\delta_{c} is in FTP, with best known complexity bound of the form Oâ‹†â€‹((Î´câˆ’1+oâ€‹(1))Îº),superscriptğ‘‚â‹†superscriptsubscriptğ›¿ğ‘1ğ‘œ1ğœ…O^{\star}\left((\delta_{c}-1+o(1))^{\kappa}\right), where Oâ‹†superscriptğ‘‚â‹†O^{\star} refers to an Oâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘‚â‹…O(\cdot) function for which all polynomial factors are suppressed, and where Îºğœ…\kappa stands for the size of the smallest cover stopping set.

As a final remark, the problem MinStop can be shown to be W[1]-hard, due to its connection to the Exact Even Set problemÂ [8].

8 Conclusion

We showed that a class of problems, pertaining to the size of the smallest stopping and trapping sets in Tanner graphs is NP-hard to even approximate. Furthermore, we showed that similar results apply to the class of LDPC codes. Our findings provide one of the few known families of codes for which the minimum distance and stopping set problems are NP-hard. We also show that a simple instance of the stopping set problem for LDPC codes, namely the complete stopping set problem, is fixed parameter tractable.
